question: This Great Lake, the second-largest by surface area, is home to over 30,000 islands, including Manitoulin Island, the world's largest freshwater island. It experiences a unique weather phenomenon known as "lake effect snow," which can produce heavy snowfall in the surrounding areas. Its name comes from a Native American tribe that inhabited the region. Name this lake, a crucial route for fur traders and explorers during the early European settlement of North America.

This state, not Illinois, was the birthplace of Abraham Lincoln in 1809, and it was also home to Fort Knox, established in 1918, which houses a significant portion of the United States' gold reserves. The state's Mammoth Cave National Park, established in 1941, is the world's longest known cave system.  Daniel Boone, a famous frontiersman, blazed a trail through the Cumberland Gap into this state in 1775, opening it up to westward expansion. Name this state with a capital of Frankfort.

This musician, nicknamed "the quiet Beatle," developed a keen interest in Indian music and spirituality, incorporating sitar and other Indian instruments into his band's music. He wrote several popular songs for The Beatles, including "Here Comes the Sun" and "Something." After the band's breakup, he launched a successful solo career, releasing albums like "All Things Must Pass." Who was this influential musician, known for his distinctive slide guitar style and exploration of diverse musical genres?

This athlete transitioned from judo to mixed martial arts (MMA) after winning a bronze medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. In MMA, she became the first UFC Women's Bantamweight Champion, known for her signature armbar submission. She was also the first woman inducted into the UFC Hall of Fame. Who is this athlete, known for her trailblazing career in combat sports and outspoken personality?

This Shakespearean play, believed to be his last solo work, features a sorcerer named Prospero who conjures a storm to shipwreck his enemies on a remote island. It explores themes of revenge, forgiveness, and colonialism through characters like Ariel, a spirit, and Caliban, a native islander. It includes a famous quote about the world being a stage and life being but a fleeting dream. What is the title of this play, notable for its magical elements and complex characters?

This 1683 battle marked the furthest westward advance of the Ottoman Empire in Europe. Polish King John III Sobieski led the defending forces, utilizing a massive cavalry charge involving over 20,000 horsemen. The siege lasted for two months and resulted in the defeat of the Ottomans, halting their expansion into Europe. What is the name of this battle, named for the capital of Austria, considered a turning point in European history?

This company has come under scrutiny for quality and manufacturing problems related to their largest commercial product. Initially establishing its headquarters in Seattle, Washington, it was founded in 1916. Known for iconic aircraft like the 747 "Jumbo Jet" and the 787 Dreamliner, it merged with McDonnell Douglas in 1997. Currently headquartered in Arlington, Virginia, it is a major player in both commercial and defense aviation. What is this American multinational corporation that designs, manufactures, and sells airplanes, rotorcraft, rockets, satellites, and missiles worldwide?

This bird of prey, which can live up to 30 years in the wild, plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance of aquatic ecosystems. It can dive at speeds of up to 100 miles per hour and its nests, called aeries, are often reused and added to each year. Its scientific name, Haliaeetus leucocephalus, comes from Greek words meaning "sea eagle" and "white head." It is not closely related to other eagles found in Europe and Asia. What is the name of this bird, a national symbol of the United States, known for its white head and tail feathers?

This animal, whose scientific name is Equus caballus, has a single toe on each foot, protected by a hoof, and its teeth continually erupt throughout its lifetime. It is a herbivore with a digestive system adapted for grazing, and its eyes are positioned on the sides of its head, providing a wide field of vision. This animal has played a significant role in human history, used for transportation, agriculture, and warfare. What is the name of this majestic creature, known for its speed, strength, and intelligence?

This athlete made her professional tennis debut in 1995 at the Bell Challenge and won her first Grand Slam title at the US Open in 1999. She has won a record 13 Grand Slam doubles titles with her sister. She holds the Open Era record for most Grand Slam singles titles, with 23 wins. She also won four Olympic gold medals, one in singles and three in doubles. Who is this dominant American tennis player, considered one of the greatest athletes of all time?

This country, known for its comic book tradition, has produced internationally acclaimed works like The Adventures of Tintin and The Smurfs. It is also home to the Atomium, a giant model of an iron crystal built for the 1958 Brussels World's Fair.  The country is divided into three distinct regions: Flanders, Wallonia, and Brussels, each with its own language and cultural identity. What is the name of this country, famous for its waffles, chocolate, and beer, located in Western Europe?

This writer, while studying medicine at I.M. Sechenov First Moscow State Medical University, wrote short stories under the pseudonym Antosha Chekhonte. He wrote about the lives of ordinary people in late 19th-century Russia, often with a melancholic and humorous tone. Some of his most famous works include "The Seagull," "Uncle Vanya," and "The Cherry Orchard." Who was this Russian playwright and short-story writer, considered a master of realism and a major influence on modern theater?

This puzzle toy celebrated its 50th birthday in 2024. It was most popular in the 1980s, when it was estimated that one-fifth of the world's population had tried it. The was originally called the Magic Cube, but it now bears the name of its inventor, a Hungarian sculptor and architecture professor. Consisting of 26 smaller cubes, or "cubies," each of the six faces is covered by nine stickers, each of one of six solid colors. Name this this puzzle which requires the solver to strategize to return it to a state where each face shows a single solid color.

This famous civil rights leader was imprisoned for larceny and breaking and entering in 1946. While in prison, he joined the Nation of Islam and became a vocal advocate for Black nationalism. He later made a pilgrimage to Mecca, which led to a shift in his views towards racial reconciliation. Name this civil rights leader, assassinated in 1965, who changed his surname to a single letter to symbolize his rejection of his slave name.

This British band, known for their elaborate stage shows and philosophical lyrics, rose to prominence during the psychedelic rock era of the 1960s. They are renowned for their use of experimental sounds, extended compositions, and concept albums. Their iconic albums, including "The Dark Side of the Moon" and "The Wall," explored themes of alienation, madness, and social critique. Who is this influential band, whose members included Roger Waters, David Gilmour, Nick Mason, and Syd Barrett, considered pioneers of progressive rock?

Born on the island of Corsica in 1769, this military and political leader rose to power during the French Revolution. He crowned himself Emperor of the French in 1804. His military campaigns, including victories at Austerlitz and Jena-Auerstedt, led to the establishment of the French Empire across much of Europe. Who was this influential figure, ultimately defeated at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815, who left a lasting impact on European history?

Launched in 2017 as an extension of "The Run-Up," this news podcast quickly garnered a massive following, reaching one million listeners a day within a year. Hosted by Michael Barbaro and Sabrina Tavernise, its weekday episodes typically feature interviews with New York Times journalists about a topical news story. What is the name of this popular podcast?

This state was the site a series of violent confrontations between pro-slavery and anti-slavery forces in the 1850s. It is also known for its significant role in the civil rights movement, as the location of the landmark Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court case in 1954. Amelia Earhart was born in this state in 1897, and it is home to the Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum.  Which state is this, nicknamed "The Sunflower State"?

This epic poem, traditionally attributed to Homer, tells the story of the Trojan War, focusing on the wrath of Achilles and his conflict with Agamemnon. It features iconic characters like Hector, Paris, and Helen of Troy, and includes scenes such as the duel between Hector and Achilles and the Trojan Horse stratagem. What is the name of this ancient Greek epic poem, considered one of the foundational works of Western literature?

This Egyptian pharaoh, known as Ozymandias in Greek, had a reign that lasted for 66 years and is believed to have fathered over 100 children. He led his armies in the Battle of Kadesh against the Hittites, resulting in the earliest known peace treaty. He also ordered the construction of the Abu Simbel temples. Who was this pharaoh, often considered one of the greatest rulers of ancient Egypt?

This Martin Scorsese film, set in South Boston, follows an undercover cop infiltrating an Irish-American organized crime ring and a mole leaking information to the mob. It won four Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director. The film's soundtrack features "I'm Shipping Up to Boston" by the Dropkick Murphys. Starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, and Jack Nicholson, it is known for its intense plot twists and gritty portrayal of Boston's criminal underworld. What is the name of this critically acclaimed crime thriller?

This insect, which has existed for over 320 million years, can survive for up to a week without its head. It can hold its breath for 40 minutes and run up to three miles per hour. Its exoskeleton contains chitin, a tough, protective substance also found in the shells of crustaceans. There are over 4,000 species of this insect worldwide, but only about 30 are considered pests. What is the name of this resilient creature, often associated with unsanitary conditions?

This mountain range is the source of the Garonne River, which flows through southwestern France. It is home to a special desman, a semi-aquatic mammal found nowhere else in the world. This range played a crucial role in the Reconquista, the centuries-long Christian effort to reclaim the Iberian Peninsula from Muslim rule. It also forms a natural border between Spain and France, and is home to Andorra, a small independent principality. What is the name of this mountain range?

This team, founded in 1901 as the Washington Senators, relocated to Minnesota in 1961 and adopted their current name. Their home stadium, Target Field, opened in 2010 and features a unique limestone façade. They have won three World Series championships, in 1924, 1987, and 1991. They are known for their "Bomba Squad" nickname, referring to their powerful offense and home run hitting ability. What is the name of this Major League Baseball team, whose mascot are named T.C. and Minnie?

This artist found his breakthrough with the painting "House by the Railroad" in 1925. His wife, Jo Nivison, was not only his life partner but also his muse and model for many of his paintings. He is best known for his depictions of solitary figures in urban settings, such as "Nighthawks" and "Automat." Who is this American realist painter, considered a master of capturing the mood and atmosphere of modern life?

This athlete, born in Sherwood Content, Jamaica, briefly played professional soccer after retiring from track. He achieved a "triple-triple," winning gold medals in the 100m, 200m, and 4x100m relay at three consecutive Olympic Games. He holds world records in both the 100m and 200m sprints, and his 100m record of 9.58 seconds has stood since 2009. Who is this athlete, considered the fastest person ever recorded?

This movement began in 1517 with the posting of the "Ninety-Five Theses," criticizing the Catholic Church's sale of indulgences. It led to the establishment of new Christian denominations like Lutheranism and Calvinism, emphasizing salvation through faith alone. The printing press played a crucial role in spreading this movement's ideas, leading to widespread religious and political upheaval across Europe. What was this 16th-century movement that challenged the Catholic Church's authority?

This politician was a Democrat from Tennesse and a vocal opponent of the Fourteenth Amendment. He served as a tailor's apprentice before his political career. He often clashed with Radical Republicans over Reconstruction which led him to be the first president to be impeached by the House of Representatives. Name this 17th US President who ascended to the presidency upon Lincoln's assassination.

These bones come in five distinct types: cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal. They are connected by facet joints and discs, allowing for flexibility and shock absorption, and they protect the spinal cord. While humans typically have 33 of these bones, the number can vary slightly from person to person. What are these individual bones that make up the backbone and support the body's structure?

This Great Lake, the smallest by surface area, is the only one that does not border the state of Michigan. It holds four times the water volume of Lake Erie and has the lowest mean surface elevation of all the Great Lakes. Home to the Thousand Islands region, an archipelago of nearly 2,000 islands, this lake was formed by glacial activity during the last ice age. What is the name of this lake, the easternmost of the Great Lakes, that borders both Canada and the United States?

This political commenator reported to prison on July 1, 2024 after being sentenced to four months in prison for contempt of Congress in 2022. This man was the acting director of the research project Biosphere 2 in 1993, and he served as an executive producer of 18 films from 1991 to 2016. He served as the White House's chief strategist for the first seven months of U.S. president Donald Trump's presidency. Name this man who helped found Breitbart news and served on the board of the Cambridge Analytica.

The TV show's theme song, "Frolic," was composed by Luciano Michelini, and its title is a satirical response to the excessive enthusiasm often seen in American society. The HBO comedy series, co-created by and starring Larry David, the co-creator of Seinfeld, is known for its semi-improvised dialogue and cringe humor. What is the name of this critically acclaimed show, which follows the misadventures of a semi-retired television writer and producer in Los Angeles?

This artist apprenticed under Filippo Lippi and was commissioned by the Medici family to paint several works, including portraits of family members. His most famous works, "The Birth of Venus" and "Primavera," depict mythological scenes with graceful figures and intricate details. Who is this Italian Renaissance painter, known for his contributions to the Early Renaissance style in Florence?

This man was born into a Muslim family in the Yunnan Province of China and was captured and castrated as a young boy, later becoming a trusted advisor to the Yongle Emperor. He commanded seven voyages across the Indian Ocean with a fleet of over 300 ships and 28,000 crew members. His expeditions were known for their massive treasure ships. Who is this Chinese explorer, diplomat, and fleet admiral, considered a key figure in China's maritime history during the Ming dynasty?

This inland sea, named for its hydrogen sulfide layer, is connected to the Mediterranean Sea through the Bosporus Strait and the Sea of Marmara. It is bordered by six countries and is a vital waterway for trade and transportation. Ancient Greek colonists once called it the "Inhospitable Sea." Which sea is this, known for its sturgeon population and its role in the geopolitical landscape of Eastern Europe and Western Asia?

This British politician was elected prime minister on July 4, 2024. He was born in London in 1962 and grew up in Surrey. In 2014, he was appointed Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath for his services to law and criminal justice. He has been Member of Parliament for Holborn and St Pancras since 2015. Name this man who has served as the leader of the Labour Party since 2020.

This Netflix political thriller, a remake of a 1990 British miniseries, was the first original series produced for the streaming platform. It follows Frank Underwood, a ruthless politician who manipulates his way to power, and his equally ambitious wife, Claire. Starring Kevin Spacey, Robin Wright, and Michael Kelly, it garnered critical acclaim and numerous award nominations. What is the name of this show, known for its dark and cynical portrayal of Washington, D.C. politics?

This state was home to the Coeur d'Alene people for thousands of years before European explorers arrived. It was admitted to the Union as the 43rd state in 1890 and is known for its vast wilderness areas, including the Frank Church–River of No Return Wilderness, the largest contiguous wilderness area in the contiguous United States. This state's capital is Boise and it was the site of the controversial Ruby Ridge incident in 1992. Which state is this, nicknamed the "Gem State?"

This Scottish-born inventor, inspired by his mother and wife's hearing impairments, initially focused on improving devices for the deaf. He founded the Volta Laboratory, where he collaborated with other scientists on various inventions. He experimented with aeronautics, developing early versions of hydrofoils and airplanes, but he is best known as the inventor of the telephone. Who was this prolific inventor, a founding member of the National Geographic Society?

This team, founded in 1968, starting playing at the Fiserv Forum in 2018. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, formerly known as Lew Alcindor, led this team to their first NBA championship in 1971. In 2021, Giannis Antetokounmpo, nicknamed the "Greek Freak," led this team to their second NBA championship, earning the Finals MVP award. What is the name of this NBA team, known for their green and cream uniforms?

This actor, known for his distinctive method acting style, received an Academy Award nomination for his breakthrough role as Michael Corleone. He is famous for his passionate delivery of lines like "Say hello to my little friend!" in "Scarface." A recipient of the "Triple Crown of Acting," he has won numerous awards, including an Oscar, two Tonys, and two Emmys. Who is this legendary actor, known for his roles in iconic films like "Serpico" and "Dog Day Afternoon"?

This body of water, containing over 250 small islands, islets, and reefs, is a crucial shipping route, with over $3 trillion in trade passing through it annually. Its Spratly Islands are claimed by six different countries, leading to ongoing territorial disputes. Historically, it was a major trade route for Chinese, Indian, and Arab merchants. What is the name of this marginal sea, a major source of geopolitical tension in Southeast Asia?

This author's debut novel, "Go Tell It on the Mountain," explored his religious upbringing in Harlem. His essay "The Fire Next Time" became a powerful meditation on race and religion in the United States. A close friend of Maya Angelou and Toni Morrison, he often explored themes of identity, sexuality, and social injustice. Who was this influential American writer?

This athlete wore the number 99, was nicknamed "The Great One," and began his NHL career with the Edmonton Oilers. He holds the record for most goals and assists in NHL history, with a combined total of 2,857 points. He won four Stanley Cup championships with the Edmonton Oilers and was awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy twice. He was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1999. Who is this legendary Canadian ice hockey player, widely regarded as the greatest of all time?

This Italian physicist invented the first electric battery in 1800, known as the voltaic pile, by stacking discs of copper and zinc. He engaged in a scientific rivalry with Luigi Galvani, whose experiments with frogs led to the discovery of animal electricity. The unit of electric potential is named after him. Who was this pioneer in the study of electrical phenomena?

This pop star has a claim to the song of the summer with her hit, "Espresso". The former child actress, who started her musical journey posting covers on YouTube, gained initial recognition for her role in the Disney Channel series "Girl Meets World."  With hits like "Nonsense" and "Skin," which became her first entry on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart, this singer-songwriter has cemented her status as a rising star. Who is this pop star?

This battle, one of the final major offensives of World War II in Europe, began on April 16, 1945. It involved over 2.5 million Soviet soldiers and 6,250 tanks, making it one of the largest battles in history. During this battle, Adolf Hitler committed suicide in his Führerbunker. The city's defenders surrendered on May 2, 1945, marking the end of the battle and a significant turning point in the war. What was the name of this battle, which ultimately led to the collapse of Nazi Germany?

This US state was the first home to the Ringling Brothers circus in 1884. Joseph McCarthy began his political career as a circuit judge in 1939 in this state, and the Republican Party was founded here in 1854. This state was historically home to the Menominee and Ho-Chunk tribes and has a capital of Madison. Name this state which is led by Governor Tony Evers.
